Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: OLC/SDSU/SDSMT Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Oglala Lakota College (OLC) proposes to extend and enhance its capability to
deliver the first two years of a Bachelor of Science degree program in engineering. This
capability will be developed through a Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative (PEEC)
established with the College of Engineering at the South Dakota State University (SDSU) and the
South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT), and is referred to as the
OLC/SDSU/SDSMT PEEC (OSSPEEC). The project will establish collaborative offerings of
gateway and bottleneck courses that occur in the first two years of engineering curricula coupled
with on-reservation hands-on laboratory and service learning experiences on the PRR that will
increase Native American student retention in pre-engineering and engineering programs across
South Dakota. A major result of this project will be the establishment of a complete two-year pre-
engineering curriculum at OLC, which will enable our students to enter any four-year
undergraduate engineering program at the junior level. Further, this project will make an
additional unique or radical step in the transformation of classical engineering education at the
state colleges participating in the collaboration.
We propose to collaborate to develop and offer the courses required for an integrated two-year
pre-engineering program at OLC and to increase the success of OLC transfer and other Native
American students at SDSU and SDSMT through shared research, internship experiences, and
community building in the third and fourth years of an engineering program. The project will be
unique in the United States in that during the collaborative process of building OLCs pre-
engineering capacity, OLCs faculty and students will be helping to transform the concept of the
first two years of the engineering curriculum at SDSU and SDSMT. This will occur through the
integration of project based service learning and undergraduate research projects on the Pine
Ridge Reservation, which will involve professors and cohorts of students from SDSU and
SDSMT. Also, these projects will cultivate closer ties among our institutions and OST Tribal
Agencies through collaborative summer research and internship opportunities on the Pine Ridge
Reservation that will lead to the development of future collaborative NSF research proposals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the goal of bringing pre-engineering and engineering to Native American and Native Hawaiian students, the National Science Foundation funded what became known as the PEEC (Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative) program. Last year, Paul Boyer joined 33 other authors to tell the story of PEEC in book form.  The PEEC project  spanned  four states: Hawai'i, North Dakota, South Dakota and Wisconsin, and it included 17 colleges and universities.  The seven-year, ongoing project included five Native Hawai'ian serving community colleges and six tribal colleges, and each partnered with at least one of six mainstream universities.  The resulting PEEC book, with editors from the South Dakota PEEC, brought together 34 advisory council members from 16 of the 17 PEEC institutions to provide guidance for the 34 authors.  The editors and authors hope that readers of the book will gain insights to help foster the intent of the unique PEEC program long into the future, particularly including tribal and Native colleges. The book has intellectual merit through leaving a lasting legacy of successes, challenges, best practices, recommendations, and hopes for the future, in order to share experiences for the benefit of practitioners of PEEC and for those with like interests at non-PEEC schools.

In previous years of the award, South Dakota State University (SDSU) collaborated with Oglala Lakota College (OLC) and South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT) to increase capacity at OLC, where they offer a pre-engineering program based on constructivist teaching principles and design throughout the curriculum.  This approach was unique in aligning engineering education with community relevant (tribal and Native Hawaiian) hands-on projects as a vehicle for students to better understand engineering activities and principles.  Through the PEEC program, SDSU was able to support more than 23 students with most earning Bachelors, Masters and PhD degrees in Engineering or STEM fields.  In a mutually beneficial arrangement, SDSU PEEC students conducted projects of importance to the Greater Pine Ridge Reservation (GPRR) community, and SDSU students boarded there each summer.  Students presented results of their research at various regional and national meetings, as well as by co-authoring publications.

A broader impact of this work was that culturally relevant, hands-on activities positively impacted the preparation and persistence of pre-engineering and engineering students, especially those who are under-represented in STEM.  Other broader impacts of PEEC are reflected in the number of Native Americans in PEEC who performed research, earned degrees and advanced degrees, wrote and published papers, and who continue to inspire others to follow in their footsteps. At SDSU, in particular, there is now unprecedented interest in outreach and in bringing Native American students to campus through the leadership of our new president, Dr. Barry Dunn, who recently set the goal of increasing Native American enrollment from 250 to 1,000 students and in building a new Native American center on campus. The SDSU PEEC cannot take credit for that, but we are in a position to welcome as many of them as possible to the Jerome J. Lohr College of Engineering at SDSU based on what we have learned from being a part of PEEC.
